Issues.Title: Added compiler change to reduce lines of code / increase readability
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
I was putting rows and columns on a grid layout and I thought it would be nice if we could add something to reduce the number of html tags. My thought is by adding a way to turn an end tag into a end and beginning tag would help reduce clutter on the Vue pages.

Example:
</b-row*>
When compiled into the dist folder or locally:

I figured making this change to html would likely not happen or take a long time. We do end tags with a /> to be self closing and reduce clutter, I was thinking it would be nice to do it the other way as well.

### What does the proposed API look like?
Not sure.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Added compiler change to reduce lines of code / increase readability" (#11871)

Issues.Title: Avoid inline styles in server-side directives (SSR) to allow nonce-based CSPs
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Currently when using the v-show directive server-side it produces style="display:none;" attributes on HTML elements. These collide with using a nonce-based CSP (content security policy level 2) setup as CSP Level 2 does not have a method to whitelist inline style attributes. CSP Level 3 allows this by using 'unsafe-hashes' and whitelisting the hash-value of the generated style attribute, but is not supported yet by all browsers (e.g. Safari). This makes it currently impossible to use a nonce-based CSP when using v-show and server-side rendering.

### What does the proposed API look like?
E.g. Allow configuration of a custom class name that is used by v-show instead of the inline-styles.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Avoid inline styles in server-side directives (SSR) to allow nonce-based CSPs" (#11864)

Issues.Title: watcher.expression is an empty string in production environment, why?
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/mqr85hg2/](https://jsfiddle.net/mqr85hg2/)







### Steps to reproduce
Open the link and view the console output.

### What is expected?
"message"

### What is actually happening?
""

---
If you change Vue to a development environment, such as https://jsfiddle.net/072nxuzt/, it is normal.

I have such a usage scenario. Register a universal watcher with vm$.watcher in mixins. Non-universal watchers will be written directly to the watcher in the *.vue file. So when I register watchers with vm$.watcher in mixins logic, I need to exclude watchers in *.vue files to avoid duplication of registration. I found that I can use watcher.expression to judge. But after my actual test, this is no problem in the development environment, but all the watcher.expression in the production environment are empty strings.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: "Attributes shorthand" in v-for cycles
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Vue is famous for its highly readable syntax and this can make it even more readable. 

### What does the proposed API look like?
Instead of writing duplicities in v-for cycles like this:

<elm
  v-for="({ value, class, 'data-image' }, key) in elmprops"
  :value="value"
  :class="class"
  :data-image="data-image"
  :key="key"
/>


Would by nice to have "attributes shorthand" like this:

<elm
  v-for="({ value, class, 'data-image' }, key) in elmprops"
  :value
  :class
  :data-image
  :key
/>


Like the object properties shorthand works in ES:

let routes = []
let router = { routes }

instead of unnecessary duplicities in older syntax:

let routes = []
let router = { routes: routes }

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue ""Attributes shorthand" in v-for cycles" (#11859)

Issues.Title: Please expose transition API?
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Many issues have requested the ability to add `.visible` modifiers to `v-show` or to implement something similar like `v-visible` in their own directives, but despite closing these issues, it has not been made possible. Exposing the transition api (`vue/src/platforms/web/runtime/modules/transition`) would make this possible.

### What does the proposed API look like?
Once upon a time the transitions API was exposed as `Vue.transition.applyTransition()`. Honestly any variant of this would be fine. I'm not sure why it was removed?

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Please expose transition API?" (#11852)

Issues.Title: Inconsistent Handling of slots.default and scopedSlots.default
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.6.11

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/nVitius/pen/ZEpxXyW](https://codepen.io/nVitius/pen/ZEpxXyW)







### Steps to reproduce
The CodePen already has everything set up. The RenderScoped component only renders this.$scopedSlots.default. The RenderBoth component renders both the $scopedSlots.default and $slots.default

### What is expected?
The documentation for [$scopedSlots](https://vuejs.org/v2/api/#vm-scopedSlots) points that $slots will be exposed in $scopedSlots in 2.6.0 .

### What is actually happening?
In cases where un-named scoped and non-scoped slots are mixed in a component, the non-scoped slots are only available in $slots.default. However, when all the slots are non-scoped, they are available in both $slots.default and $scopedSlots.default.

---
un-named non-scoped slots behave a bit differently than un-named scoped slots.
https://vuejs.org/v2/api/#vm-slots
> The `default` property contains either nodes not included in a named slot or contents of `v-slot:default`

This doesn't happen for scoped slots. If you try to create two un-named (or with the same name) scoped slots, one will overwrite the other.

I don't think that this is necessarily bad (though I don't see why they couldn't be joined). The problem is that the `render` function is supposed to assume that all the slots are available in $scopedSlots. So then you might say that whoever is responsible for writing the slots should be aware that there is an issue. 

I think the compiler should either throw a warning when this might happen (it already warns you if you try to mix abbreviated default slots and named slots). Or scoped slots should allow for multiple slots with the same name (I'm not familiar enough with the internals to know if this makes sense).

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Inconsistent Handling of slots.default and scopedSlots.default" (#11848)

Issues.Title: Issue with updateChildren method of src/core/vdom/patch.js and with removeVnodes method
Issues.Body:
Hello,

it seems that i have an issue with the updateChildren method

this method does not seems to care about keep alive, and seems to call removeVnodes in my case
and is removing keep alive components that should stay

https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/4063f3ce9bfba0132ade75ad5f907c923a561304/src/core/vdom/patch.js#L404

i tried to reproduce with jsfiddle but i failed to do so, it seems to be deeply related to vuejs core and i don't understand it so much, so i can't reproduce, this is the jsfiddle i'm working on : http://jsfiddle.net/lk77/0opq3ucx/71/

my component is deactivated and then destroyed

![Capture du 2020-12-29 14-52-28](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9606882/103288606-84d7b680-49e5-11eb-81eb-c07fd96874e2.png)

it seems related to a v-if that is unrelated but share the same parent, it seems that a sibling higher in the parent tree, with a v-if on it, can cause the keep-alive to break and the component to be destroyed. 

thanks.

- [ ] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [ ] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**

When labeling an issue, it will automatically comment and reply to remind users based on the content of the label.

### Steps to reproduce
I read the source code and found that positionStore has only set, not deleted.

The data in positionStore should be cleared on history.push() or history.replace().

The memory haspmap:positionStore will continue to grow.

Issues.Title: Cannot access router query from App.vue on mounted when route is lazy loaded
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.4.9

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/jolly-monad-ou69k?file=/src/App.vue](https://codesandbox.io/s/jolly-monad-ou69k?file=/src/App.vue)







### Steps to reproduce
* Create a Vue project with vue-router
* Add a console.log to App.vue that reads query params on created/mounted
* Create a lazy loaded route (lets say /example)
* Go to that lazy loaded route and add query params to URL (/example?q=1)
* Refresh browser

When the App.vue component loads on the lazy route (/example), the console.log returns an empty object even if there are query params. If the router view component is not lazy loaded, the console.log in App.vue will show the query params as expected.

Minimal example:
https://codesandbox.io/s/jolly-monad-ou69k?file=/src/App.vue

### What is expected?
I expect App.vue to have access to the query params on mounted

### What is actually happening?
The query params object is empty when App.vue mounts.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Cannot access router query from App.vue on mounted when route is lazy loaded" (#3439)

Issues.Title: route.query & route.meta empty on created in the root component having router-view
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.4.9

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/vue-router-routes-empty-on-load-jyl0y?file=/src/App.vue](https://codesandbox.io/s/vue-router-routes-empty-on-load-jyl0y?file=/src/App.vue)







### Steps to reproduce
1. Go to the reproduction link
2. After load, check the console

### What is expected?
I was expecting the current route's values to be filled, so as to do conditionnal stuff based on it.

### What is actually happening?
- On created it's empty
- On update it get's filled

My guess is, it's filled only when router-view is resolved.
This makes conditionnals based on route.meta or route.query impossible in the root component holding the router-view.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1426357/102704585-a61a0380-427d-11eb-9883-99d630aab784.png)

Issues.Title: Best Practice: Should we throw errors in getters if the state is undefined?
Issues.Body:
Quite often we are handling situations that require an optional state. 

E.g., my state might look like this

```
export type State = {
  isAuthenticated: boolean
  account?: Account
}
```

The initial state will always be initialized with `isAuthenticated: false`. However, we assume that account will always be set in case a user logs in to our system. The user gets fetched during the login process.

At the moment, we are writing getters in a very simple an lean way, e.G.

```
  getAccount(state: State): Account | undefined
```

However, this approach would require us to either check if the return value of getAccount is `Account` or `undefined` in our consuming components, or we would need to use type assertion ( `const account = store.getters.getAccount as Account` ) which I think is a very bad practice.

My current approach would validate inside the getter if  the state is set and throw an error if it isn't, e.g.:

```
getAccount: (state) => {
  if(!state.account) {
    throw new Error("Account isn't set")
  }
  return state.account
}
```

Which would enable me to globally catch errors that occurre in getters rather than handling it in every single component.

What are the best practices of handling optional state in getters? Am I going down the wrong path?

Thank you
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Best Practice: Should we throw errors in getters if the state is undefined? " (#1923)

Issues.Title: Expose storeKey for unit test mocking when using useStore
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
When unit testing Composition API style components, the developer may want to mock the Vuex store for testing purposes. However, due to the Vue instance not being available at setup() time, the useStore method is used in place of this.$store. This requires the developer to inject their Vuex mock, rather than using the traditional instance mocking option of the vue-test-utils mount function. Provide/inject requires a key, which, unlike $store, is not visible to the end user.

### What does the proposed API look like?
Export the default storeKey. For devs who use the default storeKey rather than providing a custom key on plugin installation, this will provide a more durable testing solution. While the key is currently the string "store", this could change in the future, leaving end users with unexpected failing tests. Vue-router has similarly exported their provide keys. I'm willing to create a PR for this.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Expose storeKey for unit test mocking when using useStore" (#1921)

Issues.Title: Vuex - check if data really can be stored in localstorage
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
We run into the following issue: 

 - An app built with Vue/ vuex works fine
 - The issue appears when the app is embedded into another third party page with an iframe
 - when the user configured the browser to reject third party cookies the browser also rejects third parties (our app) from saving data in localstorage
 - this leads to an error in browser's console and the app is not rendered, the iframe stays empty

Is there a way to check if localstorage can be used by the app? It would be helpful to avoid vuex to try to use the localstorage before really saving anything to it to avoid such problems.

### What does the proposed API look like?
No idea

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

This following correction will help developers better understand your example and eliminates confusion.

### What does the proposed API look like?
Line 6 to 8 of `ShoppingCart.vue` file is :

```
      <li
        v-for="product in products"
        :key="product.id">
```

but since `product.id` is undefined in result of computed getters `cartProducts` the `:key` attribute should be dropped. Code should simply be written:

```
      <li
        v-for="product in products">
```

Issues.Title: tree shaking not work because of vuex.mjs
Issues.Body:
### Version
4.0.0-rc.2

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/fangbinwei/vuex-next-issue](https://github.com/fangbinwei/vuex-next-issue)

### Steps to reproduce
1. yarn build
2. search `prev state` in dist/main.js to validate if bundle contains `createLogger`

https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/blob/bb7885700d7bd7afd4d12fc8be7f5b3eeaa58b0e/src/plugins/logger.js#L33

**main.js**
```js
// tree shaking not work because of vuex.mjs
import {Store} from 'vuex'

console.log(Store)
```
output(external vue)
```bash
[webpack-cli] Compilation finished
asset main.js 12.1 KiB [emitted] [minimized] (name: main) 2 related assets
orphan modules 400 bytes [orphan] 1 module
runtime modules 221 bytes 1 module
built modules 35.6 KiB [built]
  ./src/index.js   1 modules 567 bytes [built] [code generated]
  ./node_modules/vuex/dist/vuex.cjs.js 35 KiB [built] [code generated]
  external "Vue" 42 bytes [built] [code generated]
webpack 5.11.0 compiled successfully in 713 ms
✨  Done in 3.59s.
```

**main.js**
```js
// tree shaking work
import {Store} from 'vuex/dist/vuex.esm-bundler.js'

console.log(Store)
```
output(external vue)

```bash
[webpack-cli] Compilation finished
asset main.js 9.8 KiB [emitted] [minimized] (name: main) 2 related assets
orphan modules 35.1 KiB [orphan] 2 modules
runtime modules 221 bytes 1 module
./src/index.js   2 modules 35.3 KiB [not cacheable] [built] [code generated]
webpack 5.11.0 compiled successfully in 797 ms
✨  Done in 2.47s.
```

### What is expected?
 drop `createLogger` from the bundle

### What is actually happening?
bundle contains `createLogger`

---
I think tree shaking not work because of  two reasons, (I know vuex.mjs wrap vuex.cjs.js because of some rules in node)

1. vuex.mjs use `default import`
2. vuex.mjs import CommonJS(vuex.cjs.js) 

Maybe we can do like below
```diff
  "exports": {
    ".": {
+      "module": "./dist/vuex.esm-bundler.js",
      "require": "./dist/vuex.cjs.js",
      "import": "./dist/vuex.mjs"
    },
    "./": "./"
  },
```

nodejs don't support `module` in `exports`, so it can execute `dist/vuex.mjs`

[webpack support `module` in `exports`](https://webpack.js.org/guides/package-exports/#conditions), it will use `dist/vuex.esm-bundler.js` first if it is valid, since the order of `"module"` is in front of the `"import"`

### Moreover
since `vuex.mjs` wrap CommonJS which contains `require('vue')` and it let vuex doesn't compatiable with [webpack externals script](https://webpack.js.org/configuration/externals/#script), check [this issue](https://github.com/vuejs/vue-cli/issues/6149). [Reproduction link](https://github.com/fangbinwei/vuex-next-issue-external-script)

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Vuex fails to update state object with new object
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.5.1

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/millansingh/pen/dypOBjb](https://codepen.io/millansingh/pen/dypOBjb)







### Steps to reproduce
Just hit the button to run the mutation, but nothing will change which is the issue.

### What is expected?
The mutation should change the object in store, making the "output" div show 3 instead of 1.

### What is actually happening?
Nothing changes.

---
In my personal project, the state itself is unchanged, rather than a reactivity issue. I couldn't open the Vue dev tools on Codepen to check this, but I think the same thing is happening. I would expect the object in the state to be replaced with the new object, but instead it doesn't change. I've tried the Object.assign method, object destructuring, and a simple stateObj = newObj type statement. All do nothing.

Note that I can effectively get around this by looping through Object.keys of the state object and replacing them with the new object keys, but this should be possible by just replacing the object instead of using my workaround.
